item.title: Linked: The Young and the Restless
item.description:
Visit Link

Ways Into Practice is a podcast by Oslo, Norway-based Bielke&Yang created to provide students and young designers with valuable insights into the design industry and help them to make informed decisions about their careers. As part of its internship program, the interns have taken full ownership of the project, from concept development to interviews, design, and production.

item.title: Noted: New Packaging for Uoga Uoga Kids by AndStudio
item.description:
“An Eye Opener”

(Est. 2010) Uoga Uoga (which translates from Lithuanian to English as “Berry Berry”) is a natural skincare and cosmetics brand founded by Latvian-born, Lithuania-based, Lena Sokolovska. The company offers over 100 natural and organic certified products, including lip glosses and mineral foundations. Uoga Uoga Kids is an extension of the Uoga Uoga brand that offers playful, organic products crafted with natural ingredients to simplify life for mischievous little ones.

Design by
AndStudio (Vilnius, Lithuania)

Related links
AndStudio project page

Relevant quote
Turning bath time into a kid's playground, we designed the client's products as playful toys. These new friends, called Uogiai (inspired by the brand name), become exclusive bathroom buddies waiting for bath time adventures. Vibrant purple characters. with their friendly big eyes, instantly capture children's attention and invite them to play. To add another layer of fun, each package includes a unique sticker booklet. So that kids can personalize their Uogiai or create a whole collection, making bath time an exciting and engaging experience.

Images (opinion after)

Opinion
The first thing that stands out for me in this project is how both client and designer were able to take a relatively serious brand for grown-ups and translate that into a successful kid-focused brand with the same ingredients and simplicity of the parent brand. Case in point, the eyebrows in the big eyes on the packaging are made from the existing wordmark, which is a rather clever way of expanding visually, conceptually, and brand-architecturally the brand. Obviously, the main thing that stands out is the big pair of eyes on each of the various purple-colored packages. It's impossible to see it and not smile. Making the packaging even more special is a set of stickers that can be placed on the nearly blank canvas of each package. As someone who twice went through the ordeal of bathing kids, I can attest to the market's need of something like this to make bath-time more fun for the kid and more bearable for the adult because things can get heated and emotions get hurt during what should be a joyful moment in a kid's daily routine and not a scream- and tear-filled hour-long session. But I digress from my own PTSD. Overall, this is playful in the best of ways and while many kids' brand and products pander to the audience and come across as childish, this manages to maintain a fun level of design sophistication.

item.title: Reviewed: Friday Likes 512: From Mitch Wiesen, Menta, and The Young Jerks
item.description:
“From Mitch Wiesen, Menta, and The Young Jerks”

Take a shot every time I say “funky” in this post as a trio of funky, small-batch, artisanal, and hand-crafter products come together this week, with work from Philadelphia, Guadalajara, and Brooklyn.

Better Late by Mitch Wiesen

Better Late is a small-batch amaro — an Italian herbal liqueur commonly consumed as an after-dinner digestif — hand-crfated in Los Angeles by two Italian East Coasters. (The name of the product is a fun play on “amaro”, which means “bitter” in Italian.) The packaging, designed by Philadelphia, PA-based Mitch Wiesen, conveys the small-batch-ed- and hand-crafted-ness of the liqueur with a low-fi, no-pretense design featuring a condensed, reverse-contrast sans serif diagonally placed along the label. (Apologies for all the hyphenation.) The chunky, funky type is accompanied by some Italian-hand-gesture illustrations that add a touch of humor and a script on the opposite corner that reads “Bei Tempi, Tempi Lenti” (Good Times, Slow Times) — a good motto to slide into the coming weekend. See full project

Rare Beehive by Menta

Rare Beehive is a small brand of Mānuka honey harvested from the hills of Moeawatea, Taranaki, New Zealand, launched in Miami, FL, by Javier Elias García, a former professional soccer player. The identity, designed by Guadalajara, Mexico-based Menta, is spearheaded by a custom wordmark in a funky combination of straight and circular features that, in their resulting oddity, are meant to reflect “the rarity and unique characteristics of Mānuka honey”. On the packaging, the logo playfully bends around the corners of the bottle and is supported by the funky OT Jubilee reproduced in what looks to be thermography, which gives it its plastic-y, raised look. The peach and yellow color palette are quite nice and they work really well with the outer, kraft shipping packaging. A bonus icon of a Mānuka flower entwined with bee’s wings, literally seals the deal. See full project

Pa’lante by The Young Jerks

Pa’lante is a premium, artisanal rum created by a Cuban-American family, crafted in Mexico by a master blender trained in the Cuban rum-making tradition, and operating in Brooklyn, NY. The packaging, designed by local firm The Young Jerks, is delivered in their signature funky style that mixes typographic styles, lettering, and design elements as satisfyingly and as deliciously as a well crafted cocktail. In this instance, an angular wordmark anchors a diamond-shaped label as a condensed serif criss-crosses on the edges while a bevy of other bits and pieces fill in every nook and cranny. Even the information label on the back gets some typographic love. It’s worth noting that The Young Jerks also designed their previous packaging. Can’t wait for v3.0. (Sadly no case study link but a few more images can be seen on The Dieline — subscription required.) See full project

item.title: Announced: 2024 Brand New Conference: Summary, Sights, and Videos
item.description:
“An Illustrated Overview of the 2-Day Event”

Here is this year’s breakdown of the 16 sessions of the 2024 Brand New Conference that took place this past October 10 – 11 in Salt Lake City, and which was awesome. (If you are looking at this in an RSS reader head on over to the real thing, too much heavy formatting). This is a very long post with a photo of each speaker, very brief summaries, and a preview of their video/session, so give it a good time to load. A few other things worth bullet-pointing:

  • Videos for purchase are now available.
  • Videos for the 2010 to 2017 Brand New Conferences are available for free; for the 2018 conference are now reduced to $4; and for the 2023 conference are now reduced to $8.
  • A lot more photos from the event have been posted in this Flickr album.
  • Registration is now open for the 2025 Brand New Conference in Pittsburgh, PA, on October 23 – 24.
  • This year’s identity case study coming in a couple of weeks.

All event photos by Sofia Negron. (On the grid images below you can click to open a bigger version.)

Day 1: Registration

Day 1: Opening Remarks

Day 1: About the Identity

As has been the case the previous two years we ran out of time to go through everything. (Our fault — we usually simply don’t have time to rehearse and time things but we’ve made a promise to ourselves to nail it next year.)

Day 1: Early Morning Speakers

Max Ottignon / Ragged Edge

An optimistic view on how branding — specifically branding that dares to be different — presents a big opportunity for designers to help combat the onslaught of blanding, the threat of AI, and the oppressiveness of the algorithm as explained through three principles backed up by three Ragged Edge case studies.

↓ Video Preview

BUY VIDEO ↗

Duy Nguyen & Lan Mai / M — N Associates

A proud display of this duo’s roots in Vietnam — which serves as their own design playground to reflect its culture — as they share a handful of “firsts”, from their first time being featured on Brand New all the way to designing their first identity for a Vietnamese, unicorn-status company, all as they celebrate their 10 years in the business.

↓ Video Preview

BUY VIDEO ↗

Day 1: Morning Break

Day 1: Late Morning Speakers

Dhiya Choudary / Independent

A collection of five lessons learned in their still-young journey that has taken them from India to the United States; from learning as many disciplines as possible to embracing change; and from working at various agencies to working in-house to now being independent and figuring out where to apply their colorful, vibrant approach to next.

↓ Video Preview

BUY VIDEO ↗

Vanessa Eckstein / blok design

A barrage of both inspiring and challenging insights from this seasoned designer who has practiced in multiple countries and has continuously blended art, culture, society, and humanity into her work with beliefs like idealism being a preconception, chaos as a way of thinking, and uncertainty being intrinsic to the process of design.

↓ Video Preview

BUY VIDEO ↗

Day 1: Lunch Break

Day 1: Early Afternoon Speakers

Eleazar Ruiz / Odd Notion

An engaging tale of finding a purpose in this industry by creating a business that forced him to show up for his community everyday with the values he had forged since his days growing up in the Dominican Republic: embracing your difference, working hard while knowing when to siesta, caring deeply, and eliminating hurry.

↓ Video Preview

BUY VIDEO ↗

Day 1: 15-minute Flings

Kevin Cantrell / Kevin Cantrell Studio

A stunning display of switching between minimalism and maximalism, systems and illustrations, and replicability and singularity as he shares three principles to finding the happy medium as well as the flexibility among them.

↓ Video Preview

BUY VIDEO ↗

Mike Daines / Anton Klein Group

An entertaining case for embracing experimentation across process and output and how to bridge the gap between clients’ needs and a designer’s or design studio’s personal attitude, illustrated by a series of examples involving fast cars, tight deadlines, and improbable design solutions.

↓ Video Preview

BUY VIDEO ↗

Beau Oyler / Enlisted Design

A glimpse at the growing opportunities of designing for the “Creator Economy” to build brands that people care about and have an emotional connection with by turning functional products into emotional products that create an authentic experience between creators and their fans.

↓ Video Preview

BUY VIDEO ↗

Day 1: Afternoon Break

Day 1: Late Afternoon Speakers

Marisa Sanchez-Dunning / If Only Creative

A thoughtful reminder that not all careers start with a clear trajectory and that it’s never too late to self-correct as long as you have clear values of what you want to do, who you want to do it for, and why you want to do it in the first place — all, almost literally, to the tune of Miley Cyrus.

↓ Video Preview

BUY VIDEO ↗

Liza Enebeis & Christopher Noort / Studio Dumbar/DEPT®

A masterclass in how motion design and sound can bring a brand to life as this dynamic (and hilarious) duo walk us through the breadth of their work that can span from quiet and subtle elegance to heart-thumping action and how much of it is fueled by unbound and constant experimentation with different tools and techniques.

↓ Video Preview

BUY VIDEO ↗

Day 1: Summary

Day 2: Early-morning Vibes

Day 2: Brand New (the Blog) Summary

A look back at the most interesting stories from Brand New, the blog, in the last 12 months.

Day 2: Early Morning Speakers

Jordan & Jeremy Coon / Brethren Design Co

An amusing look at how these two brothers grew up together, found themselves apart early in their career, and then came back to each other to find creative freedom (as well as their own unique voice) as a team, working on breweries, restaurants, and board games while never forgetting that — fact — farts will never not be funny.

↓ Video Preview

BUY VIDEO ↗

Andy Pearson / Liquid Death

A riotous take on embracing and nurturing worst practices to build a body of work by “entertaining the parts of us that are really, really stupid” as he shares Liquid Death’s wild marketing approach to take a stand against marketing that sucks, bottled water that pollutes, and the sameness of the retail landscape that numbs the mind.

↓ Video Preview

BUY VIDEO ↗

Day 2: Morning Break

Day 2: Late Morning Speakers

Violaine Orsoni & Jérémy Schneider / Studio Violaine & Jérémy

An awe-inspiring display of craft as this duo walks us through their obsessive approach to designing that celebrates beauty, that encourages taking the time to finesse work, and that champions attention to detail over “the big idea” as evidenced in their work for the hospitality industry where their vision comes to life in real, physical objects.

↓ Video Preview

BUY VIDEO ↗

Scott Na‘auao / Welcome Stranger

An impassioned tale of NOT following other people’s dreams (or ideas of an ideal career) and instead having the conviction to do what feels right at the time paired with some insightful lessons — seen and told through his lens as a practicing designer in Hawai‘i — on what it means to responsibly shape culture as designers.

↓ Video Preview

BUY VIDEO ↗

Day 2: Early Afternoon Speaker

Robyn Kanner / Studio Mosaic

A heartfelt reminder that design — and pretty much every discipline out there — is human first, meaning we are always creating for real people with real stakes in this very real world as perfectly summed up in her contributions to high-profile political campaigns, shaped, in part, by an unexpected source: some fateful missed free throws in the 1995 NBA Finals.

↓ Video Preview

BUY VIDEO ↗

Day 2: 15-minute Flings

Adrian Orozco / Adrian Orozco

A lively collection of seven mantras for design and life that include traits uncommon to creatives — like letting go, being patient, or not comparing yourself to others — culminating in an appeal to, simply, have more fun.

↓ Video Preview

BUY VIDEO ↗

Kesia Nielsen / Braaand

An invitation to trust our intuition — just a little more — in guiding a brand’s story instead of relying solely on data, analytics, and ROI in favor of embracing your gut feelings, trusting your instincts, and tapping into your emotions.

↓ Video Preview

BUY VIDEO ↗

Day 2: Afternoon Break

Day 2: Late Afternoon Speakers

Cat How / How&How

A trio of exciting case studies that exemplify How&How’s mission to “Liberate ideas the world deserves” as she shares how consistency and bravery by her team and their clients is key to building successful, memorable, and distinct brands all while avoiding the dreaded “Sharkhorse”.

↓ Video Preview

BUY VIDEO ↗

Michael Benjamin / Studio Parkside

An unexpected and enthralling view of branding, of working with clients, and of developing a process through the world of academia by embracing his role as an adjunct professor that forced him to find a way to remove the mystery and ambiguity of what we do in order to figure out how to teach it.

↓ Video Preview

BUY VIDEO ↗

Day 2: Summary

Day 2: Closing Remarks

Day 2: After-party

Attendee Impressions

Hit refresh on your browser if they don’t show up at first. Most of the Instagram activity this year happened through Stories and we tried to capture as many as possible in two separate highlights — Day 1 / Day 2 / The That Blue Truck Experience— (but there is a limit of how many you can include).

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Re/mark Agency (@remarkagency)

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by GOLD DESIGN CO. (@golddesign.co)

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by GOLD DESIGN CO. (@golddesign.co)

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Scott Heffernan (@scottheff)


View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Pete Nguyen (@pete.nguyen)

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Each + Every (@madebyeachandevery)

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Cole Smith (@colesmxthdesigns)

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Brenna Vaterlaus (@brennavaterlaus)


View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Demi (@anhdeminguyen)

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by zoë glenn (@zoeglenn)

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Kelsey Color, LLC (@kelsey.color)

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by madilyn carruthers (@madilynann.e)



BNConf 2025: Pittsburgh, PA

The 2025 Brand New Conference is scheduled for October 23 – 24 at Heinz Hall. Pre-sale tickets available now. See you there?

item.title: Linked: As a Matter of Cursive
item.description:
Visit Link

Specifically citing that cursive writing is no longer taught universally in K-12 education as a reason for the change, Washington College in Chestertown, MD, has introduced a new logo to replace the old one that featured George Washington’s original signature in his 18th-century script. To their credit, it WAS hard to read even for anyone that was taught cursive and even with what is basically a subtitle.

item.title: Noted: New Logo and Identity for River Spirit by Grant
item.description:
“A Script Runs Through It”

(Est. 2003) “River Spirit is one of the most gorgeous golf clubs in all of North America, nestled along the edge of the Rocky Mountains. But there’s more than just beauty to this course. The layout is also among the most popular in the Province, and the amenities at River Spirit Golf Club are sure to satisfy even the most discriminating tastes. This is truly a must-play Alberta golf course. River Spirit Golf Club actually boasts three different 9-hole layouts for a total of 27 holes that can be combined into many interesting layouts. All courses at River Spirit feature four different sets of tees to ensure an enjoyable round for every caliber of golfer. However, no matter how you choose to play River Spirit, you will still find yourself among some of the most picturesque scenery in all of golf. In addition to excellent on-course play, River Spirit also boasts a 325-yard driving range, complete with grass tees, five target greens, bunkers and two practice putting greens — all of which will help you keep your score as low as possible.”

Design by
Grant (Calgary, AB)

Related links
Grant project page

Relevant quote
In an industry like Golf, it can be daunting to step outside the lines and approach your messaging differently. Luckily, this team gave us total creative freedom to explore and break the rules.

We wanted to create something that still felt classic and nostalgic but with a fresh new outlook that felt welcoming and inspiring for newbies and pros alike.

“We know your name, not your par score” was a big part of our messaging and vibe. While there are tournaments and competitions at RSGC, the crew has a genuine interest in their players and creates an environment that fosters connection. Younger, diverse generations are becoming increasingly interested in Golf, and stuffy old boys’ clubs aren’t always conducive to this much-needed energy. We steered clear of anything pretentious and opted for friendly messaging, a bold-but-natural palette, an askew checkered brand pattern, and a series of vintage-inspired golf illustrations.

Images (opinion after)

Opinion
This isn't the biggest of brands. In fact, it's pretty niche — a single golf club in Calgary, AB — but the before and after is so drastic (and the after so nice) that I thought it merited some additional attention. The old logo is almost literally a parody of someone trying to make the cheesiest logo possible. Like, it's using Papyrus. Un-ironically. And a giant dove. And some mountains. In a calligraphic style. Not good. Any change would be an improvement but the new logo is a lovely script that makes the course look elegant and upscale yet friendly and rustic. It's also a good visual manifestation of the name of the golf course with the type being flow-y like a river and air-y like a spirit (or something to that effect). The hand-drawn approach extends to the identity, first in a shorthand logo that turns the full wordmark into a monogram and pairs it with a hand-drawn flagstick and a series of charming spot illustrations, which have a fun, J. Peterman catalog vibe going. The color palette is quite nice too and hints at the general preppy-ness of golf in a way that isn't as hoity-toity as usual, aided by the fun type choices of Argent and BD Supper, both of which are welcome, quirky alternatives to the usual suspects. Overall, the various elements, while broad, are cohesive and never feel like it's one too many things going on as they all contribute to convey a quality experience infused with some quirkiness to avoid looking like it takes itself too seriously.

item.title: Reviewed: New Logo and Identity for Kleenex by Turner Duckworth
item.description:
“Wipe the Slate Kleen”

Launched in 1924, Kleenex is arguably the most well-known brand of facial tissues, often used as a prime example of a genericized trademark. Before it found its calling as an “absorbent kerchief”, the Kleenex name was first applied to a crepe paper used as a filter within gas masks during the First World War and it was first marketed as a way to remove cold cream. Developed and still owned by Kimberly-Clark, Kleenex might not be well-known for its innovations but advancements in its packaging and the make-up of its tissues to be softer or include a moisture activated layer that kills 99.9% of cold and flu viruses are part of what have kept it as the market leader. This week, Kleenex has introduced a new identity designed by Turner Duckworth.

While the Kleenex wordmark script has taken various forms since 1924 (most notably Saul Bass’ 1961 rendition), its use globally has been challenged in recent history. Several versions of the script were in rotation, and a wide variety of legibility-protecting, functional containing shapes had been introduced. Turner Duckworth set out to solve two challenges with one solution: a singular logo to be used everywhere, and a singular, meaningful containing shape that ensures the legibility of the script in all contexts.

Turner Duckworth provided text

Before getting into the review, here is a couple of things I learned today. The first is actually somewhat embarrassing as I should probably know this but I had no idea Saul Bass had designed the first iteration of the Kleenex logo we know today. The second is the origin of the Kleenex name, which, in short is a trademark-able abstraction of the world “Clean” given that it was originally used to clean up make-up. The “ex” part, though, comes from the crepe paper innovation mentioned in the introduction which was later used in another well-known Kimberly-Clark product, Kotex, which itself was a contraction of “Cotton” and “Texture”. The more you know.

At the heart of the new visual identity is a new crown holding device that houses the existing and iconic Kleenex script and creates a singular expression for the logo.

That meaningful containing shape is also the heart and soul of the new visual identity. Inspired by a crown icon that had previously played a minor supporting role in several markets, Turner Duckworth elevated it to play lead actor.

Metaphorically, a crown reinforces both Kleenex’s leadership status, as well as its core brand idea of delivering strength in everyday moments. Formally, it ergonomically hugs the script as if the script itself was drawn to inhabit it. And strategically, the crown has been drawn to hint at the shape of Kleenex’s flagship product. The comfy curves of both the script and new distinctive crown have inspired almost all aspects of the rest of the identity—particularly its typography and illustration.

Turner Duckworth provided text

For as long as most of us have been alive, the Kleenex logo has remained relatively the same and easily recognizable for its loopy script, regardless of how much or how little curvature its baseline has, or what kind of holding shape it was placed in or not, or how distracting and wild the patterns have gotten in its boxes. Despite its recognizability, the logo has indeed suffered from a lot of inconsistency in its use over the years and across countries so it makes sense to want to reign it in and establish a singular version to move forward with.

The previous logo, updated by Rob Clarke relatively recently, brought back some contrast in the thicks and thins of the loops, gave it more bounce in its baseline, and adjusted some letters – mainly the “K” and “x” — for a smoother flow throughout. The new logo makes the slightest of modifications to the script but, obviously, the biggest change is the introduction of a new holding shape that’s meant to evoke a crown as well as the image of a single tissue sticking out of the box, which naturally folds into some curves as its lightweight material defies gravity.

I have mixed feelings about it. I do like the shape and I like how ambiguous it is about what exactly it is. I instantly saw it as the top of a tissue box and I also read it as a crown but my first thought was “why the hell a crown?” as I do not associate Kleenex with anything regal in any way — visually, conceptually, or aspirationally. The soft curves of the implied crown do help avoid it coming off as trying to be a premium product or being pretentious but, still, a crown is a bit of a stretch. I also like the integration of the script wordmark into the holding shape… the two elements are well balanced, well spaced, and well aligned in their curvature but I also think they now compete with each other as both are fairly strong elements and, in a way, the holding shape now steals some of the thunder of the script which is so recognizable on its own. In the end, the holding shape does solve the huge problem that, more often than not, the wordmark NEEDS to be placed inside something to offset it from the backgrounds so might as well make that something be memorable and recognizable.

Working with type designers Alec Tear and Lewis Macdonald, Turner Duckworth developed a bespoke primary typeface, Kleenex Serif. It showcases the brand’s strength and allows Kleenex to speak in a range of tones across a spectrum of stories. Visually, the font is heavily inspired by the Kleenex script itself, and mirrors some of its nuanced details. It also shares formal qualities with the new crown symbol.

Turner Duckworth provided text

The new typeface is excellent and probably the best advancement of the Chobani-Burger King-Cooper-esque aesthetic. It’s chunky, it’s soft, it’s friendly, and it’s expertly crafted. It looks great in small and big sizes and the “fi” and “ffl” ligatures are fire.

While Turner Duckworth balanced the task of updating a heritage brand to feel relevant with respect for existing Kleenex assets, there was also an opportunity to inject a more distinctive personality. Every new asset has been designed to balance a communication of strength with an equal balance of warmth that has implicitly been a part of the brand for decades. While the new logo, color palette and typography set the foundation, a new approach to illustration drives it home.

Turner Duckworth provided text

The illustrations are, sadly, extremely generic and bland. The featureless faces are somewhat off-putting and the motion, while valiant, is a little too basic. To their credit, I do like the sparks of white color that echo the product itself and there are some nice details like the veil of the bride and the scarf of the person below echoing the contour of the new holding shape. There is this other illustration — the one directly above — that is far more interesting and unique and I would love to see more of that fun abstraction drive the illustration work. However, it must be acknowledged that Kleenex is a HUGE global brand and that it can not really take bold visual risks so the lowest-common-denominator illustrations are not necessarily the wrong approach.

While Kleenex’s core brand color has varied from market to market, the new visual identity introduces a new core color palette that elevates Kleenex Blue as the anchor color for the brand. It will be used consistently to reinforce the brand across touchpoints and markets to build equity with consumers. The secondary palette reinforces the strength and maturity, offering more variety and depth within the system.

Turner Duckworth provided text

The few applications shown that bring together the new typeface, illustrations, and tone of voice are… fine. It gets real mainstream real quick with copywriting that is almost clever but ends up a little cringey and with layouts that offer no real point of distinction. Once more in their defense, this seems like it’s the first time Kleenex has had an official identity beyond whatever its boxes are doing on the shelves so this feels like them dipping their toes in the water cautiously instead of cannon-balling into the pool recklessly.

Overall, this might have a couple of questionable elements but it does feel like the right approach and the right solutions to solve or at least address some of the brand’s challenges while infusing it with as much charm and craft as a massive mainstream product will allow.
